qas.question: What are the two symbols that signify pharmacy in English-speaking countries?

answers.text: the mortar and pestle and the ℞ (recipere) character
mortar and pestle and the ℞ (recipere) character
the mortar and pestle and the ℞ (recipere) character

qas.question: What symbol was employed until early in the 20th century?
What country uses the Bowl of Hygieia as a symbol of pharmacy?
What countries use a red stylized A to signify pharmacy?
Which countries use the green Greek cross as a symbol of pharmacy?

answers.text: France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India
France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India
France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India

plausible_answers.text: the mortar and pestle and the ℞ (recipere) character

qas.question: What are the two symbols that signify pharmacy in non-English-speaking countries?
What symbol was employed until early in the 19th century?
What country no longer uses the Bowl of Hygieia as a symbol of pharmacy?
What countries use a blue stylized A to signify pharmacy?

plausible_answers.text: France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India

qas.question: Which countries use the red Greek cross as a symbol of pharmacy?

context: The two symbols most commonly associated with pharmacy in English-speaking countries are <a0_0><a0_2><b5_0>the <a0_1>mortar and pestle and the ℞ (recipere) character<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, which is often written as "Rx" in typed text. <a1_0><b6_0>The <a1_1><a1_2>show globe<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> was also used until the early 20th century. Pharmacy organizations often use other symbols, such as the Bowl of Hygieia which is often used in <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>the Netherlands<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, conical measures, and caduceuses in their logos. Other symbols are common in different countries: the green Greek cross in <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>France, Argentina, the United Kingdom, Belgium, Ireland, Italy, Spain, and India<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>, the increasingly rare Gaper in <b7_0>the Netherlands<b7_0/>, and a red stylized letter A in <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b8_0>Germany and Austria<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> (from Apotheke, the German word for pharmacy, from the same Greek root as the English word 'apothecary').
